byline.original: By BENJAMIN WEISER and SUSANNE CRAIG

abstract: Federal trial of former New York State Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver begins with prosecutors accusing him of selling his office and his defense lawyers saying Silver's conduct in office was perfectly legal; vastly different portrayals of Silver's actions mirror gulf between way prosecution and defense frame culture in Albany.
lead_paragraph: The prosecution said Mr. Silver, a former State Assembly speaker, had sold his office, while his lawyers argued he was a force for good.

headline.main: Lawyers Offer Contrasting Views of Sheldon Silver as His Corruption Trial Starts
headline.print_headline: Lawyers Offer Contrasting Views of Ex-Speaker as His Corruption Trial Opens

snippet: The prosecution said Mr. Silver, a former State Assembly speaker, had sold his office, while his lawyers argued he was a force for good.
